item.title: DARPA ODIN BATL (2017-2020)
item.description:
The US Government uses biometrics to identify persons of interest, but biometric presentation attacks can prevent correct identification. The goal of the Odin program is to develop biometric presentation attack detection technologies to ensure biometric security systems can detect when someone is attempting to disguise their biometric identity.

In order to test Odin’s ability to detect presentation attack approaches, a red team approach may be used to evaluate the performance of Odin technology. This will be facilitated by two components of Odin. Thor will develop presentation attack detection technology, and Loki will exercise Thor technology. As security vulnerabilities in government systems may be classified, Loki will be issued as a classified broad agency announcement.

In the BATL project of the ODIN program, the University of Southern California’s (Computer Science Department), the Idiap Research Institute, (Switzerland), Darmastadt University of Applied Sciences (Germany), TREX Enterprises and Northrop Grumman are developing novel presentation attack detection technologies.

item.title: DARPA MediFor SAVI (2016-2019)
item.description:
Historically, the U.S. Government deployed and operated a variety of collection systems that provided imagery with assured integrity. In recent years however, consumer imaging technology (digital cameras, mobile phones, etc.) has become ubiquitous, allowing people the world over to take and share images and video instantaneously. Mirroring this rise in digital imagery is the associated ability for even relatively unskilled users to manipulate and distort the message of the visual media. While many manipulations are benign, performed for fun or for artistic value, others are for adversarial purposes, such as propaganda or misinformation campaigns.

This manipulation of visual media is enabled by the wide scale availability of sophisticated image and video editing applications that permit editing in ways that are very difficult to detect either visually or with current image analysis and visual media forensics tools. The forensic tools used today lack robustness and scalability, and address only some aspects of media authentication; an end-to-end platform to perform a complete and automated forensic analysis does not exist.
DARPA’s MediFor program brings together world-class researchers to attempt to level the digital imagery playing field, which currently favors the manipulator, by developing technologies for the automated assessment of the integrity of an image or video and integrating these in an end-to-end media forensics platform. If successful, the MediFor platform will automatically detect manipulations, provide detailed information about how these manipulations were performed, and reason about the overall integrity of visual media to facilitate decisions regarding the use of any questionable image or video.

In the SAVI project of the MediFor program, SRI, the University of Amsterdam and the Idiap Research Institute (Switzerland) are working on the detection of Audio-Visual Inconsistencies.

item.title: ODESSA (2016-2018)
item.description: This project named ODESSA (Online Diarization Enhanced by recent Speaker identification and Structured prediction Approaches) is in partnership with LIMSI and EURECOM in France.

item.title: BIOWAVE (2016-2017)
item.description:
BIOWAVE “BIOmetric Watch Activated by VEins" 
Research on wrist vein biometrics funded by the CTI agency.
Collaborative project with BIOWATCH ( http://www.biowatch.ch ) and CSEM ( http://www.csem.ch/site/ ).

item.title: Google Mobile AS* (2015-2016)
item.description:
Confidential Google research project on mobile biometrics.

* Principal Investigator and Coordinator.

item.title: SWAN (2016-2019)
item.description:
SWAN “Secure Access Control over Wide Area Network" http://nislab.no/biometrics_lab/swan  
Research on face, perioccular and speaker recognition robust to presentation attacks (anti-spoofing) on mobile devices.

.

item.title: TeSLA (2016-2018)
item.description:
TeSLA “An Adaptive Trust‐based e‐assessment System for Learning" 

Research on trustworthy face and speaker recognition robust to presentation attacks (anti-spoofing).

.

item.title: UniTS (2015-2018)
item.description:
UniTS “Unifed Speech Processing Framework for Trustworthy Speaker Recognition" http://nislab.no/biometrics_lab/swan  
Research on speaker recognition robust to presentation attacks (anti-spoofing).

.

item.title: Google ATAP*(2015)
item.description:
Google ATAP research sprint on mobile biometrics.

* Only lab in Europe invited to join the sprint.

item.title: HFACE* (2014-2017)
item.description:
HFACE “Heterogeneous Face Recognition" 
Research on face recognition across sensors.

* Principal Investigator and Coordinator.

item.title: COHFACE* (2014-2015)
item.description:
COHFACE “COntactless Heartbeat detection for trustworthy FACE Biometrics" 
Research on remote photoplethysmography: estimation of the heart-beat from face video images.

* Principal Investigator and Coordinator.

item.title: Swiss Center for Biometrics Research and Testing* (2014--)
item.description:
Swiss Center for Biometrics Research and Testing http://www.biometrics-center.ch

Funded by the Swiss State of Valais to promote research and testing in Biometrics.

* Principal Investigator and Coordinator.

item.title: EMMA1* (2014-2015)
item.description:
Confidential research project funded by Doctor Web.

* Principal Investigator and Coordinator.

item.title: LOBI* (2014-2015)
item.description:
LOBI “Low Complexity Binary Features for Robust-to-Noise Speaker Recognition" 
Research on speaker recognition.

* Principal Investigator and Coordinator.

item.title: BEAT* (2012-2016)
item.description:
BEAT “Biometrics Evaluation and Testing" http://www.beat-eu.org  
Reproducible Research on presentation attacks for face, speaker and vein recognition.
Development of the BEAT platform ( https://www.beat-eu.org/platform/ )

* Principal Investigator and Coordinator.

item.title: CONTEXT* (2011)
item.description:
CONTEXT “Context Modeling for Object Detection" 
Research on an unified boosting framework for object detection including face detection and keypoint localization.

* Principal Investigator and Coordinator.

item.title: TABULA RASA* (2010-2014)
item.description:
TABULA RASA “Trusted Biometrics under Spoofing Attacks" http://www.tabularasa-euproject.org  
Research on presentation attacks for face, speaker and vein recognition.

* Principal Investigator and Coordinator.

item.title: REPLAY* (2010)
item.description:
REPLAY “Face authentication robust to replay attacks" 
Research on presentation attacks to face recognition.

* Principal Investigator and Coordinator.

item.title: BBfor2 (2010-2013)
item.description:
BBfor2 “Bayesian Biometrics for Forensics" http://bbfor2.net

Research on generative models for face and speaker recognition.

.

item.title: MOBIO* (2008-2010)
item.description:
MOBIO “Mobile Biometrics" http://www.mobioproject.org  
Research on mobile biometrics: face and speaker.
